awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Integrating Artificial Intelligence in Computer Science majors at Hampton University
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue science, technology, engineering or mathematics (STEM) graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Hampton University will enhance undergraduate education in the Computer Science department to prepare students to meet the needs of the workforce related to Artificial Intelligence (AI) or advanced studies in AI. Undergraduate students are involved in the project as researchers and peer tutors. 

The key goal of this project is to integrate artificial intelligence modules and assignments into core computer science courses to increase students' career preparation, knowledge, and professional skills related to an area of artificial intelligence. The three specific activities will be to: develop artificial intelligence modules and course-relevant assignments; reform the core computer science courses; and enhance the current advanced elective courses, such as Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, and Data Science.  The project will disseminate its findings widely and have significant broader impacts on the education of African American computer science majors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The Department of Computer Science implemented Artificial Intelligence (AI) modules/assignments into the CSC core courses to increase Computer Science major students’ AI knowledge and skills.  This provides students with a background and skillsets to meet the new challenges of our growing global society through computer science and AI.

 The following are overall accomplishments:

  1. AI Modules/Assignment Integration: Core CSC Courses have integrated AI module(s) and/or assignment(s) to enable students graduating in the Department of Computer Science overview of Artificial Intelligence.
  2. New AI-related Elective Courses: The Department of Computer Science continues to offer CSC 430 Artificial Intelligence, and now we have additional elective courses related to AI, including Robotics. In addition, we offered CSC 191 and CSC 291 Research Topics in Computer Science where students are now conducting their research in Artificial Intelligence.
  3. New Degree: Newly BS degree in Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning, approved in 2022 and first course offered Fall 2024.
  4. Undergraduate Research in AI: Increase the number of students’ undergraduate research in Artificial Intelligence from 22% in 2022 to 29% in 2023 and to 40% in 2024 for CSC 425 Research Projects.  
  5. Impact on Non-CS majors: Students from other disciplines who enrolled in CSC 120 Introduction to Computers, CSC 151 Computer Programming I, and CSC 152 Computer Programming II will receive AI awareness training and assignments as a part of these courses. 

 


Last Modified: 12/18/2024
Modified by: Chutima Boonthum-Denecke

por.por_txt_cntn:
The Department of Computer Science implemented Artificial Intelligence (AI) modules/assignments into the CSC core courses to increase Computer Science major students AI knowledge and skills. This provides students with a background and skillsets to meet the new challenges of our growing global society through computer science and AI.


The following are overall accomplishments:

AI Modules/Assignment Integration: Core CSC Courses have integrated AI module(s) and/or assignment(s) to enable students graduating in the Department of Computer Science overview of Artificial Intelligence.
New AI-related Elective Courses: The Department of Computer Science continues to offer CSC 430 Artificial Intelligence, and now we have additional elective courses related to AI, including Robotics. In addition, we offered CSC 191 and CSC 291 Research Topics in Computer Science where students are now conducting their research in Artificial Intelligence.
New Degree: Newly BS degree in Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning, approved in 2022 and first course offered Fall 2024.
Undergraduate Research in AI: Increase the number of students undergraduate research in Artificial Intelligence from 22% in 2022 to 29% in 2023 and to 40% in 2024 for CSC 425 Research Projects.
Impact on Non-CS majors: Students from other disciplines who enrolled in CSC 120 Introduction to Computers, CSC 151 Computer Programming I, and CSC 152 Computer Programming II will receive AI awareness training and assignments as a part of these courses.
